newsitem.title: INDIA: Indian rice prices fall despite Chinese inquiries.
newsitem.headline: Indian rice prices fall despite Chinese inquiries.

text.p: Indian rice traders have received inquiries from Chinese firms for imports but no deals have been finalised and export prices are falling on a lack of foreign demand, traders said on Wednesday.

Prem Garg, managing director of a leading Delhi foodgrain export company, said some Chinese firms had made inquiries for the import of about 50,000 tonnes of rice but no deals have been finalised. "It is still in the negotiation stage," Garg said.
Analysts said they did not expect the Chinese sales to be consumated as China insists on quality checks at the port of delivery -- a condition not agreeable to India exporters.
"Rice exports to China are not likely to materialise as China insists on delivered weight and quality whereas India wants to deal in shipped weight and quality," said one analyst.
They said Indian rice exporters are not prepared to wait for payment until consignments are discharged at the port of delivery. Shipments to China normally take about 40 days.
Export rice prices have dropped between $10-$15 a tonne in past two weeks due to a fall in foreign demand, traders said.
Indian five percent broken was quoted at around $300 a tonne FOB, 10 percent broken at $280, 15 percent broken at $255 and 25 percent broken at $240.
